Graphical abstract Different hybrid silica-encapsulated metallocene catalysts were prepared by a non-hydrolytic sol-gel method and evaluated in ethylene polymerization. The employed organic groups to modify the silica network were methyl, octyl, octadecyl, vinyl, phenyl, chloropropyl, iodopropyl and glycidoxypropil and the encapsulated catalyst was bis(cyclopentadienyl)zirconiun IV chloride. The catalysts were characterized in terms of zirconium content, structure and texture via Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, x-ray absorption spectroscopy, nitrogen porosimetry and small angle x-ray scattering and morphology by transmission electronic microscopy. The polymerzation activity results varied in the range of 1650–2850 kg PE/mol Zr.p.h, showing an increase for all the hybrid materials if compared to the non-hybrid one. Polymers characteristics such as crystallinity, melting temperature and molecular weight were shown to be affected by the nature of the organic moieties present on the catalyst support. These findings highlight the material potentiality for tuning the product characteristics depending on the organosilane present on the catalyst system. Keywords Non-hydrolytic sol-gel Silica Ethylene polymerization Zirconocene 1 Introduction Metallocene are the most studied catalysts in the ethylene polymerization process nowadays. These high activity single site catalysts can be activated by methylaluminoxane (MAO) producing polymers with narrow molecular weight distribution [1–3]. From the industrial point of view, the heterogenization of these compounds is demanding aiming at its suitability to the existing processes and polymers manufacturing plants (drop-in technology) [4]. One of the well established approach of catalyst heterogenization is the immobilization of these compounds on inorganic supports, particularly on silica [5–7]. In this scenario, distinct research groups have reported the effects of the use of bimetallic catalysts viz-a-viz monometallic species [8]; the effect of the support thermal treatment or its pre-treatment with cocatalyst on the resulting active polymerization sites [9,10]; or the influences of the surface heterogeneity on single-site species [11,12], just to mention a few. The use of silica prepared by the sol-gel process involving supported catalysts for ethylene polymerization use has been restrained to grafting/impregnation reaction onto silica surface, which had been previously prepared or modified [13,14]. Metallocene sensitivity to humidity and air has prevented other approaches dealing more directly with the sol-gel synthesis, which in turn involves water and alcohol. However, this picture has been changed with the development of water-free non-hydrolytic sol-gel routes, which can be performed under inert atmosphere [15,16]. Exploiting this type of strategy, it is possible to achieve the encapsulation of catalyst molecules, once it is present since the beginning of the silica network formation [17,18]. Our research group has reported the encapsulation and performance of different metallocene catalysts encapsulated within silica network. Initial studies evaluated the bis(cyclopentadienyl) zirconium dichloride (Cp2ZrCl2) being encapsulated in silica obtained by the non-hydrolytic process varying the proportion of the tetraethoxysilane precursor (TEOS) and SiCl4. This study showed the catalyst activity maintenance, after encapsulation procedure, reaching intermediate polymer amounts between the homogeneous and grafted catalysts. Furthermore, molecular weights were increased when compared to the catalyst in its homogeneous form [19]. Subsequent studies also showed the method efficiency for a series of different metallocene catalysts. These materials microstructure was also investigated suggesting dependency of polymer productivity with the process of silica grains fragmentation during the polymer chain growth [20]. Other aspects and the addition of other oxide types to the silica network were further investigated. For instance, a mixture of silica and titania was obtained by the non-hydrolytic route, resulting in materials that can produce polymers with high molecular weight and also can be activated with lower cocatalyst amounts [21]. This last outcome was also found when tungsten oxide was generated. A variation in the electronic density on the Zr metal center was noticeable in this case, showing that it is possible that the catalyst has been partially activated by the support [22]. It is worth noting that the search for lower amounts of cocatalysts implies lower costs, while the use of lower amount of cocatalyst may provide lower aluminum residues in the final material, which in turn may reduce the potential nuisable effect on polymer properties. Other types of oxides like chromium and molibdenium oxides are also under investigation [23,24]. In addtion, ultra-high molecular weight polymers with oriented crystalline structure could be obtained by the encapsulation of titanium metallocene catalysts. The results showed polymers with fibrous microstructure obtained directly from the polymerization process [25]. This phenomenon seems to be originated from the structure organization of the silica employed as the matrix for this catalyst. A series of staked up plates-like morphology were observed, which can facilitate this process. The obtained fibrous polymers microstructure can improve mechanical properties of the material if compared to the regular ones [25]. After such interesting results achieved with the non-hydrolytic sol-gel route for polymerization catalysts encapsulation, it is necessary to consider the questionnings regarding some aspects of interest in terms of industrial application. Nowadays, the possibility of polymers with broad molecular weight distribution production employing metallocene catalysts is still under investigation by industries [26–28]. In addition, it is of high interest to have a system that can be tuned to generate specific characteristics according to a desired application [6,29,30]. Although the immobilization of metallocene catalysts has already been extensively explored, to the best of our knowledge there are no reports describing the encapsulation of this compounds using hybrid silicas. Thus, this investigation reports the preparation of different hybrid catalysts by encapsulation of Cp2ZrCl2 via non-hydrolytic sol-gel route using eight different organosilanes combined with TEOS. The aims of this approach was to create different domains around the catalyst center which would cause small differences on the catalyst center, which in turn would potentially broad the polydispersity of the resulting polymer. The hybrid encapsulated metallocenes were evaluated in ethylene polymerization using methylaluminoxane (MAO) as the cocatalyst. A series of complementary techniques were employed to investigate the influences of the different organosilanes on catalyst properties and activity and on the produced polymers characteristics. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Materials Silicon tetrachloride (SiCl4) (Sigma Aldrich, 99%), tetraethoxysilane (C0) (TEOS, Merck, 98%), methyltriethoxysilane (C1) (Sigma Aldrich, 90%), octyltriethoxysilane (C8) (Dow Corning, 90%), octadecyltrimethoxysilane (C18) (Sigma Aldrich, 90%), vinyltrimethoxysilane (Vy) (Dow Corning, 98%), phenyltrimethoxysilane (Ph) (Dow Corning, 97%), chloropropyltrimethoxysilane (Clp) (Wacker silicones, 98%), iodopropyltrimethoxysilane (Ip) (Sigma Aldrich, 95%) and glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane (Gp) (Sigma Aldrich 98%) were used as received. Iron (III) chloride (Neon, 98%) was dried under vacuum. Toluene (Nuclear, 98.5%) was purified by distillation with metallic sodium and benzophenone. Ethylene gas was purchased from White Martins (99.95). All the procedures were conducted under inert atmosphere of argon (Air Liquide, ultra-pure 99.99%). 2.2 Catalyst preparation The synthesis procedure was adapted from reference [19] and all the procedures were performed under inert atmosphere, utilizing the Schlenck technique. Firstly, 1 mL of toluene was added to 75 mg of Cp2ZrCl2 and 10 mg of FeCl3 (catalyst of the sol-gel reaction) in order to solubilize the Cp2ZrCl2. Then, SiCl4, TEOS and organosilane in the 3.3:1.7:1 ratio were added to the first mixture. The sol-gel reaction proceeded at 70 °C until complete gelification. After gelification, the solid was dried by vacuum for 2 h, and it was then milled and sieved (mesh # 270) under inert atmosphere. Samples for control, without the presence of metallocene Cp2ZrCl2, were also studied for comparison. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The catalysts zirconium content was determined by Induced Coupled Plasma Optic Emission Spectrometer (ICP OES) model Optima 2000 DV (Perkin Elmer, Massachusetts, USA). Ultra-pure Argon (99.996% White Martins) was employed as the plasma (15 L min−1), auxiliary (0,2 L min−1) and nebulizer gas (0,6 L min−1). Nitrogen (99.998% White Martins, 2 L min−1) was employed for optical system purge. Sample solutions were introduced using a GemCone nebulizer (Perkin Elmer) and clyclonic nebulizer chamber. Sample flow was 2 mL min−1 and applied radio frequency power was 1300 W. Peak signal in area was processed using 7 points per peak for the integration and automatic integration mode with 1–5 s of integration time. Standard samples were purchased from Merck in stock solutions of 1000 mg L−1 and sequentially dilluted for the achievement of 5 points in the calibration curve in the range of 0–2 mg L−1 (0, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0 and 2.0 mg L−1). In order to enable the catalyst solution preparation, 100 mg of each catalyst sample was previously diggested in 2 mL of HF at 160 °C during 6 h. 3 mL of HNO3 were added to the resulting solid and the sample was kept again at 160 °C during 6 h until complete solubilization. The resulting liquid solution was completed with ultrapure Milli-Q water until 50 mL. This last solution was dilluted 100 times and then analyzed in the ICP OES. The analyses were carried out in triplicate and the Zr content was determined according to the calibration curve. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed at the Synchrotron Light National Laboratory (LNLS, Campinas, Brazil). A SPECSLAB II (Phoibos-Hsa 3500 150, 9 channeltrons) SPECS with Al Kα (E = 1486.6 eV) source operating at 15 kV, Epass = 40 eV, pass of 0.6 eV and aquisition time of 2 s per point. Samples were deposited on carbon tape attached to a steel sample holder in a glovebox and transfered to pre-chamber under inert atmosphere. The inital pressure at the analysis chamber was 1 × 10−9 Torr. Binding energies of C 1s, Cl 2p, Zr 3d e Si 2p were calibrated according to C 1s peak at 285 eV providing accuracy of ±0.2 eV. Data analyses were perfomed using CasaXPS® software. Zr K edge experiments were collected at the XAFS1 beamline [31] at LNLS in transmission mode using a Si(200) monochromator and 3 ionization chambers. A Zr metal foil was used to calibrate the monochromator and was always kept at the third ion chamber as an internal calibration reference for each scan. Samples were mounted in a holder and sealed with Kapton® tape in a glovebox prior to the measurement at the beamline. The spectra were collected in the range 17850–18980 eV using 1 eV step in the x-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and 2 eV in the extended x-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) region and 3 s per point. Several scans (4–7) were averaged in order to get a good signal to noise ratio. The XANES data were background subtracted and normalized. The EXAFS data were treated using a standard data analysis that is a linear background subtraction, determination of the absorption edge and extraction of the EXAFS oscillations with a 5 order polynomial. The Fourier Transforms were performed with a Kaiser-Besser window of ωk = 8 Å−1. Two programs were used to treat the data, the Winxas [32] and the IFEFFIT package [33]. Phase shifts and amplitudes were calculated for Cp2ZrCl2 [34] using the ATOMS [35] and FEFF7 program [36]. Attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectra were recorded in absorbance mode on a Perkin Elmer FT-IR spectrophotometer (model Spectrum Two). The spectra were measured over the range of 4000–500 cm−1 (32 scans, 4 cm−1 resolution). A Micromeritics Gemini surface area analyzer was used for the nitrogen sorption studies. The samples were preheated at 150 °C for 8 h under vacuum before each measurement. The specific surface area was determined by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method at −196 °C, in the partial pressure range of 0.01 < P/P0 < 0.35. The pore sizes were calculated by the Bartt-Joyner-Halenda equation (BJH method) using Halsey standards. Small angle x-ray scattering (SAXS) experiments were carried out on the D2 A and D11A beamlines at the Brazilian Synchrotron Light Laboratory (LNLS, Campinas, Brazil) using a wavelength λ = 1.488 nm. The X-ray beam was monochromatized by a silicon monochromator and collimated by a set of slits defining a pin-hole geometry. The incident beam was detected at two different sample-to-detector distances (1549.8 mm and 2245.7 mm) to increase the scattering vector q (q = (4π/λ) sinθ ; 2θ = scattering angle) range. The dried samples were sandwiched between two Kapton® foils in glovebox under inert atmosphere, and the collimated X-ray beam was passed through a chamber containing the stainless steel sample holder. All measurements were performed at room temperature. Silver behenate powder was used as standard to calibrate the sample-to-detector distance, the detector tilt and the direct beam position. Transmission, dark current and Kapton® foil corrections were performed on the 2D image before further data processing. The isotropic scattering patterns were radially averaged. SAXS data analysis was performed using the Irena evaluation routine [37] implemented in the Igor Pro Software (WaveMetrics, Portland, USA) [38]. A multi-level unified fit was used to describe one or two levels of structural organization evident in the scattering data [34,35]. In this method, the scattering provided by each structural level is the sum of a Guinier exponential form and a structurally limited power-law tail. A generalized equation, representing any number of levels, can be written as [39,40]: (1) I q = ∑ i = 1 n G i exp − q 2 R gi 2 3 + B i exp − q 2 R g i+1 2 3 erf q R gi / 6 3 q Pi where n is the number of structural levels observed, G is the Guinier prefactor, R g is the radius of gyration and B is a prefactor specific to the power-law scattering which is specified as the decay of the exponent P. The catalysts morphology was investigated using transmission electronic microscopy (TEM). Samples were milled and suspended in ethanol using ultrasound equipment during 30 min. The suspensions were then deposited in a copper grid. The images were acquidred in a JEOL microscope, JEM-1200 model operating at120 kV. 2.4 Ethylene polimerization The ethylene polimerization reactions were performed in a glass reactor, with ethylene pressure (99.99% UP, White Martins) of 1 bar. Initially, 150 mL of toluene were added to the reactor equipped with a water jacket to control the temperature. Once the solvent was at 60 °C, an amount of methylaluminoxane cocatalyst (MAO, 10% toluene solution, Chemtura Europe) equivalent to Al/Zr ratio of 1000 was added to the reactor. The solid catalyst was suspended in 5 mL of toluene and added to the reaction, after medium saturation with ethylene gas, in a concentration of 10−5 mol L−1. Ethylene gas flow (1 bar) was kept throughout the whole reaction. After 30 min, the reaction was stopped by acidified ethanol addition and the products were then filtered and dried. 2.5 Polymer characterization Diferential scanning calorimetry was employed to investigate cristallinity and melting temperature. The analysis was performed in a DSC-4 calorimeter from Perkin-Elmer using a 10 °C min−1 cooling and heating rates in the temperature range of 30–160 °C. The heating cycle was performed twice and only the second scan was considered avoiding thermal and mechanical samples history. The average molecular weight and polydispersion were investigated by gel permeation chromatography (GPC) with high temperature in a 150 CV chromatograph from Waters equipped with refraction index detector and three columns (Styragel HT3, HT5 and HT6E). The analysis were performed with 2 mg of the sample in 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene (TCB) at 140 °C and 1 mL min−1 flow of TCB. The columns were calibrated with standard solutions of PS, PEBD and PP. The data deconvolution was obtained using the distribution model of Flory. 2.6 Statistical analysis Data regarding correlation analysis presented during this study were obtained using the SPSS® software. The analysis was performed by the comparison of all the obtained parameters of characterization (triplicate) among themselves. The results showed different correlations (positive or negative) and they were considered significant at the level **p < 0.01 and *p < 0.05. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effects of the organosilane in the percentage of loaded Zr The percentage of the reported Zr content refers to the total amount added during the synthesis. The differences found are a result of the total mass of formed material (hybrid silica) and do not represent the capacity of retention of the metallocene, once there was no washing process to remove the fraction that was not encapsulated. On the other hand, previous leaching studies have demonstrated that the released amounts were lower than 1% from the total amount of Cp2ZrCl2 added. Table 1 presents the percentages measured by the ICP OES after digestion of the heterogeneous catalysts. The results revealed percentages ranging from 1.1 to 3.5 wt.-% of the Zr, with values around 2.5 wt.=% as average. Zr contents obtained by grafting processes use to present lower values, i.e. less than 1%, although some higher values as 1.5% can be obtained depending on the support in terms of number of OH sites available for immobilization and zirconocene complex in terms of steric effects of the fixed metallocenes on the surface [1,41,42]. The lowest amount represents the synthesis with higher mass yield, leading to lower concentration of Cp2ZrCl2 catalyst in silica and vice-versa to the higher values. Even though these amounts do not reflect the ability of the organosilane employed for encapsulated compunds retention, this content was determined since it is important to the evaluation of the catalyst performance in terms of catalytic activity, as well as for the obtained polymers characteristics. 3.2 Effect of the nature of the organosilane on the encapsulated catalyst structure The organosilane effects on the nature of the zirconium catalytic species were investigated by x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The number of species and the binding energy (BE) of each Zr species were determined in order to be afterwards correlated with the catalytic activity and with the characteristics of the resulting polymers. The region between 175 eV and 195 eV, corresponding to Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2, was deconvoluted as illustrated in Fig. 1 for CP-C0, CP-C8, CP-C18 and CP-Clp. According to Fig. 1 the two different Zr species, bearing different electronic density could be observed, as resulting from the signal deconvolution. Table 2 shows the BEs of the set of encapsulated systems. For instance, for CP-C0 (non-hybrid sample), two signal were observed centered at 183 eV and 184.8 eV, whilst Cp2ZrCl2 in its free form (bare zirconocene) presents peaks at 182.4 eV and 184.8 eV, respectively assigned to Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2. When the organosilanes were added to the silica matrix, it was possible to observe a shift to lower BE values, indicating that the presence of this organic moieties impinged a higher electron density on the metal centers. The only exceptions for this trend were the CP-Ip for the species with higher electronic density and the CP-C1. In these two cases, the resulting species were shown to present lower electronic density. According to Table 2, BE was also shown to be dependent on the nature of the employed organosilane. The averaged values occurred around 182 eV to the species with higher electronic density and 182–185 eV to the lower electronic density ones. Besides the energy shift, the peaks also presented changes in their shape. CP-C18 showed a different peak profile with similar energy to CP-C8, but differently from the others. Most of the species presented lower electronic densities. The CP-C8 sample also presented a shift of its entire peak to smaller values of energy, showing that in this case the Zr bears higher electronic density. CP-C1 presented a broad peak if compared to the other samples, showing a higher difference between the two Zr species. In addition, x-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) was used to probe the atomic local environment around Zr. The Zr K edge XANES spectra of all the catalysts (Fig. 2 A and B) are quite smothered as expected for 4d and 5d transition metals. All the spectra present the 1s → np transition at about 18010 ± 1 eV. The spectra of CP-C8, CP-C1, CP-Gp and CP-Ph display closer similarity to the one of pure Cp2ZrCl2 powder (Fig. 2A). More intense XANES features are observed for CP-Gp, indicating a less distorted Zr site for this catalyst. For CP-Vy, CP-C18, CP-Clp, CP-C0 and CP-Ip the edge is less intense, the XANES features are broader and shifted to higher energy (Fig. 2B). For the CP-Ip catalyst one observes a damping of the main absorption edge and the presence of the shoulder at 18,030 eV indicate stronger modifications around Zr for this catalyst. The EXAFS signal of the bare Cp2ZrCl2 (Fig. 2) is a broad sine function. The spectrum of CP-C8 presents the closest resemblance to the one of bare Cp2ZrCl2. All the other spectra display clearly different patterns with well defined shoulders resulting from the interference of different bond distances. The Fourier transform of Cp2ZrCl2 displays two large peaks at about 1.8 and 2.8 Å (uncorrected from the phase shift) that correspond to the coordination shell and the next nearest neighbor (NNN) contribution around Zr. Excepting CP-Ip, all the FT´s have both peaks and the major difference is a lower intensity for the coordination shell, what indicates a higher disorder around Zr for all these catalysts. In the fitting procedure there are several difficulties since in Cp2ZrCl2 the Zr atom is surrounded by chlorine and carbon atoms at similar distances. The analysis of the Cp2ZrCl2 with crystallographic data obtained from a cif file [34] shows that the Zr-Cl and Zr-C distances are similar and since their EXAFS signals are out of phase it results in a destructive interference [43]. For this reason it is difficult to simulate a mixed shell with C and Cl atoms and sometimes very low coordination numbers or unreliable results such as negative Debye Waller factors or high energy shifts are found. So the different patterns for the EXAFS oscillations may be due changes in the degree of distortion of the Zr atom with the Cp and chlorine yielding to different average distances for the Cp and the chlorine bonds. The Zr environment is less affected for CP-C8. For this reason in this study the only quantitative result extracted was the bond length. The fitting of the coordination shell of the catalysts with Cl or C yielded an average bond distance of 2.40 ± 0.02 Å. The only exception was for CP-Ip that yielded an average bond distance of 2.46 ± 0.02 Å. This difference indicates that the coordination number of Zr is higher for the CP-Ip catalyst. The observed modification is in agreement with the higher intensity of the Fourier Transform first peak for this catalyst. It was not possible to determine the origin of the peak at about 2.8 Å. 3.3 Effect of the organosilane on the catalysts structural characteristics The structural characteristics were further evaluated by FTIR-ATR and the spectra are shown in Fig. 3 . It was possible to identify the hybrid silica organic groups and the cyclopentadienyl ring of Cp2ZrCl2. Bands regarding to the CH3 and CH2 stretching were identified at ∼2980 cm−1 to asymmetric νCH3, ∼2920 cm−1 to asymmetric νCH2 and ∼2860 cm−1 to symmetric νCH2. These bands were more intense for the material prepared with octadecylsilane (CP-C18), since it has higher content of these groups. The CH bending vibration occurred in the region of 1440–1465 cm−1. In addition, the bands corresponding to the silica network were assigned at ∼1040 cm−1 to asymmetric νSi-O(Si), ∼790 cm−1 to symmetric νSi-O(Si) and the region of 550–570 cm−1 to Si-O- rock [44]. The vibrations corresponding to the encapsulated compound Cp2ZrCl2 were found at ∼1390 cm−1 which corresponds to the Cp ring CC bonds stretching. In some cases, a small band/shoulder around 1150 cm−1 overlapping the dominant silica Si-O(Si) band in the region was also identified to CC stretching. The C–H deformation in the plane of Cp ring occurs at ∼970 cm−1 and appears overlapping with the silica Si-O(H) stretching, which is of low intensity as a result of the non-hydrolytic process. The hydroxyl groups were probably formed after air/humidity contact, since the analyses were not performed under inert atmosphere. Lastly, it was possible to identify the CH deformation outside the plan around 700 cm−1 for some samples [44,45]. 3.3.1 Relations between vibrational spectra with the silica network structure The SiO(Si) band of silica is a network vibration one and it could be employed to the network structure evaluation. A complete analysis of its components might involve the deconvolution in the LO and TO modes. Each mode has contributions related to the main units of siloxane rings: The four-member units (SiO)4 and the six-member units (SiO)6. Hence, the band will be composed by four basic components: The longitudinal component for the four-member (LO4) and six-member (LO6) rings and the transversal component for the same rings with six (TO6) and four (TO4) siloxane units [46,47]. Therefore, the network structure was determined in terms of six-membered siloxane rings (SiO)6 percentage according to Eq. (2). Results for the hybrid catalysts and controls (blank sample without encapsulated CP2ZrCl2) are shown in Table 3 . The percentages varied broadly in the range of 7–76 % and it was possible to observe a decrease in (SiO)6 content when Cp2ZrCl2 was added. The exceptions were the materials such as CP-Vy and the small variations of CP-C8 e CP-C18. (2) ( S i O ) 6 = 100 × A L O 6 + A ( T O 6 ) A L O 6 + A L O 4 + A T O 4 + A ( T O 6 ) The lowest values were found to CP-C18 control and CP-Clp catalyst. Samples with bigger groups showed lower percentages of (SiO)6 rings. This percentage will be higher, the faster the gelification process occurs, since these species will be formed before the more stable ones are in the solution. Therefore, precursors with bigger volume, which use to have slower gelification process, would form higher percentage of four-membered siloxane rings. This behavior is a result of the higher thermodynamic stability of the four-membered rings. On the other hand, when the sol-gel reaction is faster, like to CP-Vy and CP-Gp, a higher amount of six-membered rings are formed, since they are more kinetically favorable. 3.4 Effects of the organosilane on the catalysts microstructure The catalyst microstructures were further investigated using nitrogen porosimetry and small angle x-ray scattering (SAXS). Surface area values determined by BET method and the structure parameters determined by SAXS are summarized on Table 4 for the different catalysts and their controls (blank sample). According to the results, it is possible to observe that the surface area decreases with the addition of the catalytic component. This behavior is a result of encapsulation of Cp2ZrCl2 in the silica network pores. Furthermore, the values show a big influence of the hybrid silica organic groups volume and functional group on the textural properties, since the areas had a wide variation depending on the group. The surface area is quite important in the case of catalysts for olefin polimeralization. One of the main limitations imposed by low specific areas is the potential difficulty of olefin access to the metallic active sites during the polimeration process. This is such important that commercial silicas for this type of catalysts preparation usually present high specific areas, around 230–250 m2 g−1 [48]. The catalyst microstructures were also investigated using SAXS to evaluate the formation and aggregation of silica particles. The results showed that almost all the materials prepared by non-hydrolytic route presented strong correlation for the primary particles. This kind of correlation identified by SAXS means that the scattering of primary particles suffers the effect of the presence of neighboring particles. Therefore, it is possible to determine an average distance (center-to-center) and also an average number of neighbors for these particles. Fig. 3 shows examples of typical curves for the catalysts and their respective controls. From Fig. 4 it is possible to observe a structure composed of three hierarchical levels of organization for both materials in the measured scale and this was a trend for all studied catalysts. This behavior of organization in hierarchical structures has already been seen in previous studies regarding mixed oxides and it has helped to explain the catalysts performance in terms of activity [20]. Moreover, it is noticeable that the presence of Cp2ZrCl2 can strongly influence the structure as shown by the differences between the CP-C0 and its control curves. Yet for the CP-Ip sample this phenomenon was not observed. The curves fitting outcomes to all samples utilizing the unified model are also found on Table 3. Rg1 represents the radius of gyration of the primary particles; P2 represents the fractal dimension of the second level according to the classification: 1 < P < 3 for mass fractal and 3 < P < 4 for surface fractal; Rg2 is the radius of gyration of the second level particles; and P3 is the fractal dimension of the third level. Since the SAXS analysis results in a series of different parameters, the Pearson correlation analysis was employed to evaluate the relationship between the different parameters and characteristics analized. Both the correlation distance and the number of neighbors of the primary particles were influenced by the volume and concentration of Zr in the samples. The larger the volume of the organic groups utilized, the greater was the center-center distance between the neighbor particles and also greater the number of neighbors observed. The center-center distance is more influenced by the organic groups volume (r Sp  = 0.597 for p < 0.01) than by the concentration of Cp2ZrCl2 catalyst (r Sp  = −0.424 for p < 0.05). However, an opposite behavior was observed for the number of neighbors (r Sp  = 0.316 for p < 0.05 for the groups volume and r Sp  = −0.644 for p < 0.01 for Zr concentration). Samples with larger radius of gyration also presented greater number of neighbors (r Sp  = 0.393 for p < 0.01) and smaller center-center distances (r Sp  = −0.305 for p < 0.05). The Rg values analysis also show (r Sp  = −0.382 for p < 0.01) that bigger particles arrange themselves in less dense fractal structures (P2) generating a following level with smaller P2 values (rougher surface fractals or less ramified structure to mass fractals). The Rg2 values, relating to the radius of gyration of the second level particles, showed a strong correlation (r Sp  = 0.553 for p < 0.01) with the Zr concentration. This correlation shows that the greater the percentage of Zr in the sample, the larger was the Rg2. This behavior may indicate that the Cp2ZrCl2 added could be immobilized among the primary particles, leadind to the bigger second particle of level 2. In addition, materials presenting greater values of P3 also presented greater Zr content, indicating that denser particles with rougher surface are, therefore, formed in the third level. 3.5 Morphological characteristics The catalysts morphological characteristics were investigated by transmission electronic microscopy (TEM). The resultant images are shown on Fig. 5 and they presented different characteristics according to the organosilane employed for the material preparation. The Cp-C0 sample presented particles that appear to be a cluster composed of other even smaller particles, which is in agreement with SAXS results. With the organosilanes addition, this cluster appearance changed to a more solid structure where the small particles could not be observed. For CP-C1 it is already possible to notice a more compact structure with less number of small aggregate particles. CP-C8 showed not defined shape particles similar to CP-C1 and also the presence of nanoparticles formation. CP-C18 and Cp-Vy exhibited only particles with not defined shape and different thicknesses. CP-Ph, CP-Ip and CP-Gp presented characteristics of overlaping layers as stacked-plates morphology. Finally, CP-Clp also presented particles that are composed of very small particles. However, in this case the small particles are not as defined as for CP-C0. 3.6 Effect of the organosilane in the polymerization activity and polymers characteristics The non-hydrolytic route has been mainly employed for the preparation of mixed oxides that are utilized for catalysis applications in several reactions [17,18]. In our research group, mixed oxides have been studied for olefin polymerization using diferent encapsulated catalytic species [19,22,23]. Therefore, this previous knowledge based on the present study on olefin polymerization using hybrid silica materials prepared by the non-hydrolytic route. The hybrid catalysts performances were evaluated in terms of catalytic activity and polymer properties. Results of activity, average molecular weight (Mn), weight average molecular weight (Mw), polydispersion (PD = Mw/Mn), crystallinity and melting temperature (Tm) are shown in Fig. 6 . Polymer yields were reported in Table S1 of supplementary information. Polymerization activity results (Fig. 6A) varied in a range of 1100–2500 kgPE/molZr−1 p−1 h−1 and they can be separated in three different groups. CP-C0 presented the lowest average activity, but it is statistically equivalent to the other catalysts with the exception of CP-C1 and CP-C8. These two latter presented the best performances; wherein the most elevated activity CP-C8 is even statistically equivalent to CP-Clp, CP-Ip and CP-Gp. These outcomes indicate that organosilanes could be employed to increase the activity of polymerization catalysts. We speculate that these organic groups can help the monomer difusion in the silica network and also they can assist as active site protectors. Thereby, the catalysis process could be maintained during longer periods, increasing productivity. The literature regarding hybrids as support for metallocenes catalysts indicates that the activity is increased when the support has high acidity due to network modifications. This would lead to an increase of catalytic sites stability and, therefore, higher activity [49,50]. Values around 3000 kgpol molZr −1 for the homogeneous and ∼1300 kgpol molZr −1 for supported metallocenes are reported in the literature [19]. The Pearson correlation analysis showed that the activity tends to be smaller when the radius of gyration of secondary particles (Rg2) is smaller. Previously, it was also found that the Rg2 is bigger for higher contents of Zr (r Sp  = 0.553 for p < 0.01) and this may indicate the immobilization of the catalytic molecule within these particles (second level). Therefore, the correlation for activity may suggest that this immobilization could hinder the access to Zr active sites, decreasing the activity. The correlations also seems to demonstrate that higher Zr contents present lower activities, which could be a result of bimolecular deactivation by the proximity of active sites [51]. Moreover, the statistic analysis suggests that the rougher the surface of the larger structure identified by SAXS (level 3), the higher the activity (r Sp  = −0.481 for p < 0.05). This may indicate that smoother surfaces may render difficult the monomer diffusion in the catalyst matrix, affecting its performance. In addition, the EXAFS signals showed the similarity between the bare catalyst Cp2ZrCl2 and the most active prepared system CP-C8 demonstrating the preservation of chemical neighborhood after encapsulation can be an important parameter to consider. Crystallinity and Tm results are shown in Fig. 6B, with values ranging from 62 to 70% and 132 to 136 °C, respectively. The CP-C8 catalyst, which presented the highest activity, also produced the polymer with lower crystallinity. The higher values were found for CP-Gp, CP-C18 and CP-Vy samples. The correlation analysis for this characteristic indicates that a higher cristallinity was found for catalysts with higher Zr content (r Sp  = 0.503 for p < 0.01), greater percentage of six-membered siloxane rings (SiO)6 (r Sp  = 0.450 for p < 0.05) and lower number of neighbors (r Sp  = −0.576 for p < 0.01). This behavior may indicate that catalysts with more opened structure could lead to more organized chains and with higher packing degree. Observing Tm results in Fig. 6B, it is possible to observe an inverse trend if compared to cristallinity. This occurs because more organized and packed chains will also need more energy to melt. The inverse behavior was also verified by correlation analysis, where exactly the same correlations were found, however in opposite direction. The literature shows outcomes with interesting increases of molecular weight of polymers prepared by metallocene supported on mesoporous hybrid silicas utilizing sulphonic acid group as modifiyer [50]. However, in the studied case, Fig. 6C and D bring results regarding GPC that show decrease of polymers molecular weight by the addition of organosilanes to the silica network. Polydispersion (PD) values were not shown to be broaded in relation to the non-hybrid silica catalyst. The higher results of PD for the hybrid catalysts were found to CP-C8 and CP-Clp. The correlation analysis for these characteristics showed an opposite tendency to that one observed for activity: it was found greater Mn and Mw values for greater values of Rg2 and P3 (r Sp  = 0.528 and 0.499 for p < 0.01, respectively). Thus, it is speculated that a greater number of monomer units are inserted in the same chain when the number of available active sites is smaller. This hypothesis is based on the previous observation where the activity was decreased when Rg2 is greater, indicating occlusion of the molecules of catalyst in its interior. The decrease could also be a result of hindering the monomer diffusion by too smooth surfaces. Both facts can lead to a limitation of the amount of available sites. Table 5 brings a comparison of the obtained results with the literature where similar systems are reported, i.e. Cp2ZrCl2 heterogenized on silica and tested in ethylene polymerization in similar reactor and experimental conditions. The hybrid supports have similar behavior to other reported experiments in average. However, some of the organic groups as C8 and Clp and also the non-hydrid support have raised the PD over the already described results. In addition, higher activity was achieved using C8 and high molecular weight for C0. In order to better evaluate the molecular weight distribution, the GPC curves were deconvoluted and are shown on Fig. 7 . The results present once again that the introduction of organic groups to the silica network leads to a significant change to the polymer structure. Observing the maximum position corresponding to each fraction, it is possible to notice that the formation of the higher molecular weight chains seem to be more affected by the organosilane introduction than by the organosilane type itself (green curve). A decrease or even a disappearance of this fraction of high Mw could be observed. This behavior indicates a suppression of the active sites responsible for generating long polymeric chains as a result of the pendant organic group introduction. Amongst the hybrid catalysts, this higher molecular weight fraction was more pronounced only for CP-C8 and CP-Clp samples. These were also the hybrid catalyst with higher values of polydispersion. On the other hand, the total suppression of this fraction was found for CP-C1, CP-C18, CP-Ip and CP-Gp. These differences show that the organosilanes can be in fact employed to modify the polymer properties. From these preliminary results further studies may be conducted. The variation of the organosilane content and even the employment of a combination of these can be used to perform a tuning of the final product properties according to its application requirements. 4 Conclusions This investigation presented a non-hydrolitic sol-gel method to prepare hybrid silica based polymerization catalysts by the encapsulation of a zirconocene compound. We have observed an increase on catalytic activity for all the hybrid catalysts if compared to that non-hybrid one. This may indicate a charge balance on the zirconium active site, which is promoting the polymer formation. The silica modifications with aliphatic chains (methyl and octyl organosilanes) presented better results in terms of activity. In terms of polymer properties, it was possible to observe different characteristics for different functional groups used as hybrid modification. Therefore, this approach could be also used, after suitable optimization, to modify the polymer characteristics according to the desired application. Acknowledgments L.C. coredata.dc:description: Different hybrid silica-encapsulated metallocene catalysts were prepared by a non-hydrolytic sol-gel method and evaluated in ethylene polymerization. The employed organic groups to modify the silica network were methyl, octyl, octadecyl, vinyl, phenyl, chloropropyl, iodopropyl and glycidoxypropil and the encapsulated catalyst was bis(cyclopentadienyl)zirconiun IV chloride. The catalysts were characterized in terms of zirconium content, structure and texture via Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, x-ray absorption spectroscopy, nitrogen porosimetry and small angle x-ray scattering and morphology by transmission electronic microscopy. The polymerzation activity results varied in the range of 1650–2850 kg PE/mol Zr.p.h, showing an increase for all the hybrid materials if compared to the non-hybrid one. Polymers characteristics such as crystallinity, melting temperature and molecular weight were shown to be affected by the nature of the organic moieties present on the catalyst support. These findings highlight the material potentiality for tuning the product characteristics depending on the organosilane present on the catalyst system.
coredata.dc:title: Hybrid silica based catalysts prepared by the encapsulation of zirconocene compound via non-hydrolytic sol-gel method for ethylene polymerization
